description: Number of iterations of phi(n) needed to reach 2.
comments: This sequence is additive (but not completely additive). [_Charles R Greathouse IV_, Oct 28 2011]Shapiro asks for a proof that for every n > 1 there is a prime p such that a(p) = n. [_Charles R Greathouse IV_, Oct 28 2011]
links: Reinhard Zumkeller, Table of n, a(n) for n = 2..10000
P. A. Catlin, Concerning the iterated phi-function, Amer Math. Monthly 77 (1970), pp. 60-61.
T. D. Noe, Primes in classes of the iterated totient function, JIS 11 (2008) 08.1.2, sequence C(x).
Harold Shapiro, An arithmetic function arising from the phi function, Amer. Math. Monthly, Vol. 50, No. 1 (1943), 18-30.
formula: a(n) = a(phi(n))+1, a(1) = -1. - _Vladeta Jovovic_, Apr 29 2003a(n) = A003434(n) - 1 = A049108(n) - 2.From _Charles R Greathouse IV_, Oct 28 2011:  (Start)Shapiro proves that log_3(n/2) <= a(n) < log_2(n) and alsoa(mn) = a(m) + a(n) if either m or n is odd and a(mn) = a(m) + a(n) + 1 if m and n are even.(End)
maple: A032358 := proc(n)    local a,phin ;    if n <=2 then        0;    else        phin := n ;        a := 0 ;        for a from 1 do            phin := numtheory[phi](phin) ;            if phin = 2 then                return a;            end if;        end do:    end if;end proc:seq(A032358(n),n=1..30) ; # _R. J. Mathar_, Aug 28 2015
